Course Description: THIS COURSE EXAMINES THE INTERRELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND ACCOUNTING TO PREPARE STUDENTS TO BE KNOWLEDGEABLE BUSINESS ADVISORS. THE COURSE PRESENTS CONCEPTS AND TERMINOLOGY OF ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND THEIR USE IN ACCOUNTING AND AUDITING DECISION MAKING. TOPICS ALSO INCLUDE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FUNDAMENTALS, RESPONSIBILITIES AND BUSINESS IMPLICATIONS.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
1.	EXPLAIN THE BASIC ROLE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY PLAYS IN A BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT.
2.	DESCRIBE THE ROLE AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF AN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY DEPARTMENT.
3.	DESCRIBE BASIC INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FUNDAMENTS SUCH AS HARDWARE, SOFTWARE, SYSTEMS OPERATIONS AND DISASTER RECOVERY.
4.	IDENTIFY FINANCIAL STATEMENT AND BUSINESS IMPLICATIONS OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY.
5.	IMPROVE RESEARCH, ORAL AND WRITTEN COMMUNICATION SKILLS.
6.	DISCUSS PRINCIPLES OF ETHICAL AND PROFESSIONAL BUSINESS CONDUCT.
Transfer Status: GUARANTEED TRANSFER TO INSTITUTION OFFERING SAME COURSE.
